messages.msgSnippet: Hi Ron, It still could have a Tokugawa/Matsudaira connection, they just weren’t samurai anymore, but that should not stop someone from putting their mon on
messages.messageBody:
Hi Ron,



It still could have a Tokugawa/Matsudaira connection, they just werent
samurai anymore, but that should not stop someone from putting their mon on
their swords habaki. Also, your point about gendai is very important as
that is just what it is. Any blade made after the haitonorei or banning the
wearing of swords is a gendai. A gendai and a gunto are not the same thing.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of Ron Hartmann
Sent: Wednesday, April 04, 2007 1:08 AM
To: token_kenkyu_kai@...; nihontostudy; nihonto@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Yamon Naokatsu



Thanks everyone, for your imput about this mon habaki on my Yamon Naokatsu
katana. Soon after I sent out this question it dawned on me that by Meiji 4
the Tokugawa were no longer in power and therefore, a meaningful connection
between this sword and the Tokugawa would be unlikely. But I'm glad I asked
since this did bring about some on-line discussion.

Interestingly, this sword which was owned for years by a good friend and
eventually came to me last year, looks and feels much like a gendaito which
I guess, it really is when you think about it. It is a very stoutly build
and very masculine blade although made relatively short in length (63.7 cm).
My other nidai Naokatsu which is dated 1865 is more a Nambokucho copy,
measuring 77.9 cm with O-gissaki. I find it interesting to see the
comparison in so few years but at a time of great "change" in Japan. It does
surprise me that Naokatsu still had a patron at this time of change in
power.

Ron
STL

messages.subject: Yamon Naokatsu
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all - Does anyone know of any connection that Yamon Naokatsu (2nd generation) had with the Tokugawa? Reason I ask, I have a short katana by Shoji Yamon
messages.messageBody:
Hi all -

Does anyone know of any connection that Yamon Naokatsu (2nd generation) had with the Tokugawa? Reason I ask, I have a short katana by Shoji Yamon Naokatsu (dated Meiji 4 - 1871) which has a silver habaki with the Tokugawa aoi crest on it in sukashi (pierced). I believe this habaki was original to the sword (not a collector's replacement) but so far I've yet to find some connection between the smith and the Tokugawa.

Thanks,

Ron
STL
